utterances: Well, Senator Domenici, thank you very much for your time today.
Thank you, Neal, bye-bye.
You are listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
Another factor in this year's outcome is early voting.
34 states and the district of Columbia allow it, and all states except absentee ballots.
An estimated 10 million people have already voted.
Joining me now is NPR senior Washington Editor Ron Elving.
And Ron, welcome back.
10 million people have already voted, and analysts are saying that this is good for Barack Obama.
Why?
Because a lot of early votes probably indicates there's going to be heavy turnout.
And the theory is that high turnout would benefit Barack Obama.
All the polls show that, the wider you make the voting base, the better he does.
The more narrow you make your screen for likely voters, the better John McCain does.
All right, let's turn to the McCain campaign.
His numbers are improving just a little bit on his handling of the economy.
What can he do this week to turn it around?
He needs to focus on what he would do to make people's economic prospects better.
He needs to let people know that he is on top of a plan for the crisis that has faced our financial industry and also that he is ready to make the economy better, whatever that may take.

He would not be ideologically rigid, that he wouldn't be tied to any past policies, particularly not those of the Bush administration, and that he would be willing to think fresh on all the questions that affect mortgage loans, all the questions that affect the downturn in the economy most generally, and to do whatever it takes to get the country out of the recession that's now pretty much officially under way.
So, I guess he's trying to do that with his talk about Barack Obama's spreading the wealth around and saying that he's a socialist.
Is that connecting at all?
The tax issue is related clearly to economy because, as John McCain says, the last think you want to do in bad times is raise anyone's taxes.
So, he can segway into the tax issue, which has always been a strong closing issue for Republican candidates.
People do expect their taxes to get higher.
They expect Democrats to be more likely to raise their taxes.
So that's an issue that can help bring some points back to John McCain.
Ron, an interesting story at Politico today talking about a high level of white support for Barack Obama, that he has even potentially more white support than Bill Clinton did.
Yes, that's right.
Bill Clinton topped out at 43 percent of the white vote in 1996.
Now, for a Democratic candidate, that was doing quite well, and with his disproportionate share of the black and Hispanic vote, more than enough to reelect him as president in 1996.
But Barack Obama's actually out-performing that now, and he is doing better than any Democrat has done among white people since Jimmy Carter in 1976.
But no Democratic candidate for president has actually won the white vote outright since Lyndon Baines Johnson in 1964 44 years ago.
So, if these numbers hold out, that would be truly remarkable for a black candidate to win more white votes than any candidate since LBJ.
Yes, for any Democratic candidate since LBJ.
It would be, in a sense, ironic that it took an African-American candidate to finally do that much better among white voters.
Ron, we are a week away.
What is the end game in these final days?
The end game is that Barack Obama is gong to want to sound presidential and start talking as though he's going to bring the country together if he wins.
John McCain still has to be on the offensive.
He still has to close the sale and try to overhaul Barack Obama.
And both candidates are going to be focusing pretty much on the same list of states.

There are six toss-up states both candidates feel they have a shot in, feel they need to win, and going from west to east, they are Nevada, Colorado, Missouri, Ohio, and then North Carolina and Florida.
NPR Senior Washington Editor Ron Elving, thank you, Ron.
Thank you, Madeleine.
From NPR News, it's Day to Day.
State and federal authorities have announced investigations into the failure of Washington Mutual Bank and into excessive spending at American International Group, that's the huge insurance company.
Marketplace's Nancy Marshall Genzer joins us now.
Nancy, if these investigations turn up wrongdoing, what can be done to punish these companies?
AIG is broke, and Washington Mutual is bankrupt.
But you have had a situation where liberals in years past sought a federal solution to the issue of abortion, while the conservatives fought to--wanted to fight it out on state levels.
Here at Getty House each week, Caputo and other volunteers escort classes of fourth-graders though the mansion.
They explain its history as a reflection of Los Angeles' history.
On the sunny fourth floor, in the home gym that functions as an ad hoc classroom, Caputo runs through the curriculum.

And we teach them a little bit about the city flag, the city seal, who their mayor is, who their City Council representative is, where the name of our city came from--which is, right here on the board, El Pueblo de Nuestra Senora la Reina de los Angeles Porciuncula.
Wow, that's a mouthful.
But even if they don't remember their city's complete name, children do remember that they visited the mayor's house.
And who knows?
One of these kids might run for mayor in the future and win, and actually live here.
Karen Grigsby Bates, NPR News, Los Angeles.
Those pictures not clear enough of the LA mayor's mansion and the gardens?
You can go to our Web site and see real pictures there at npr.org.
Thank you, Karen.
(Soundbite of music)
I'm Alex Chadwick.
More just ahead on DAY TO DAY from NPR News.
Chicago, in the 1970s and '80s, had a notorious group of police officers known as the midnight crew.
They tortured more than 100 black and Latino men into confessions.
Decades later, Chicago is trying to make amends, in part, with payments the city is calling reparations.
Noel King from our Planet Money podcast talked to some of the victims about what the money means to them.
When Darrell Cannon heard the city of Chicago would mail him a check for almost $100,000, he was like, uh-uh.
I went and got it.
Why?
Because I don't trust them (laughter).
I don't trust the system.
I don't want you talking about - we sent it.
Oh, you haven't gotten it yet?
You know.
Darrell doesn't trust the system because he spent 24 years in prison after the police tortured him into a confession.
A few weeks after he got his check, I went to visit Darrell at his house on the South Side.
Can I get you anything - pop, water...
I asked him how he was spending the money.
And he said family mostly.
He sent some cash to his kids and grandkids.
His brother passed.
Darrell paid for the funeral.
He bought his wife a diamond ring.
His car and his phone were both old junkers, so he traded up.
Beautiful car.
You know, it's not too...
What color is that?
That's gold?
I like to call it champagne.
Champagne.
Yes ma'am.
I like that.
Very eloquent and nice.
Tell me about your phone - your Galaxy...
Oh, yeah, this is the Galaxy 6.
I had told myself that whenever I got some money, I was going to turn in my Galaxy 3 and get me a Galaxy 6.
That phone is champagne too, isn't it?
Almost.
While I was visiting with Darrell, he got a call from an old friend, Anthony Holmes.
Anthony.
Yeah.
